fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • Talking about Siberia's booming business in digging up and selling "mammoth ivory", an article said that Russia is exporting 60m tonnes of this substance annually to China. It meant 60 tonnes (Is mammoth ivory really the ethical choice?, 28 September, page 3, G2). • An analysis piece said that London's mayor has been moving on to Labour turf with calls for more funding of transport and housing. "Such demands," it added, "have reached a crescendo since May." When it means a gradual increase in loudness or intensity, crescendo is fine; the difficulty comes when it's teamed with "reached". The Guardian's style guide explains: "Musically or figuratively, [crescendo] is the build-up to a climax, not the climax itself" (And in the red corner ... it's both Ken and Boris, 25 September, page 9). • Homophone corner, speaking of the debate over the extent to which Britain should cut its budget deficit: "The IMF ... backed early retrenchment on the grounds that the recovery is gathering strength. That is uncertain, and while it remains so a rigid timetable of cuts is not a cautious but a wreckless proposition (Decision time, 28 September, page 34). • A Shortcuts item about a website that allows readers to sample the 99th page of a book said that contrary to Mary Poppins's advice, the very beginning is not necessarily a very good place to start. It was Maria in the Sound of Music who sang those words (Never judge a book by its cover, just try page 99 instead, 28 November, page 3, G2).
